meanings.definition: To draw into the mouth by contracting the muscles of the lips and mouth to make a partial vacuum.
meanings.sent1: Babies often suck on pacifiers for comfort.
meanings.sent2: I like to suck on lollipops to enjoy the sweet taste.
meanings.sent3: Why did the straw suck up all the juice so quickly?
meanings.sent4: The vacuum cleaner can suck up even the tiniest pieces of dirt.
meanings.sent5: The black hole seemed to suck everything into its depths.

meanings.sent1: I think the movie will suck because the reviews were bad.
meanings.sent2: The old vacuum cleaner started to suck at picking up dirt.
meanings.sent3: The idea to wear socks with sandals would really suck.
meanings.sent4: The leak in the boat caused it to suck in water rapidly.
meanings.sent5: The broken straw would always suck air instead of liquid.

meanings.sent1: It would suck if someone stole my lunch from the fridge.
meanings.sent2: The taste of spoiled milk can really suck.
meanings.sent3: The prank to put salt in the sugar bowl would suck for the next person.
meanings.sent4: The smell of rotten eggs can really suck the joy out of a room.
meanings.sent5: The sight of the overflowing trash can really suck.
